segment.source: 4911(S) Resource attributes of the object were changed.
segment.target: 4911(S) Resource attributes of the object were changed.

segment.source: Describes security event 4911(S) Resource attributes of the object were changed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4911(S) Resource attributes of the object were changed.

segment.source: 4911(S): Resource attributes of the object were changed.
segment.target: 4911(S): Resource attributes of the object were changed.

segment.source: This event generates when resource attributes of the file system object were changed.
segment.target: This event generates when resource attributes of the file system object were changed.

segment.source: Resource attributes for file or folder can be changed, for example, using Windows File Explorer (object’s Properties-Classification tab).
segment.target: Resource attributes for file or folder can be changed, for example, using Windows File Explorer (object’s Properties-Classification tab).

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2012, Windows 8.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2012, Windows 8.

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that changed the resource attributes of the file system object.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that changed the resource attributes of the file system object.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that changed the resource attributes of the file system object.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that changed the resource attributes of the file system object.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “Security” value for this event.
segment.target: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “Security” value for this event.

segment.source: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: The type of an object that was accessed during the operation.
segment.target: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: The type of an object that was accessed during the operation.

segment.source: The following table contains the list of the most common Object Types:
segment.target: The following table contains the list of the most common Object Types:

segment.source: Object Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and/or name of the object for which resource attributes were changed.
segment.target: Object Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and/or name of the object for which resource attributes were changed.

segment.source: Handle ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal value of a handle to Object Name.
segment.target: Handle ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal value of a handle to Object Name.

segment.source: This field can help you correlate this event with other events that might contain the same Handle ID, for example, “4663(S): An attempt was made to access an object.”
segment.target: This field can help you correlate this event with other events that might contain the same Handle ID, for example, “4663(S): An attempt was made to access an object.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “0x0”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “0x0”.

segment.source: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process through which the resource attributes of the file system object were changed.
segment.target: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process through which the resource attributes of the file system object were changed.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Original Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the old resource attributes.
segment.target: Original Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the old resource attributes.

segment.source: If no resource attributes were set to the object, then SDDL will not contain any attributes, for example “S:AI”.
segment.target: If no resource attributes were set to the object, then SDDL will not contain any attributes, for example “S:AI”.

segment.source: New Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the new resource attributes.
segment.target: New Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the new resource attributes.

segment.source: See more information in Resource AttributesOriginal Security Descriptor field section for this event.
segment.target: See more information in Resource AttributesOriginal Security Descriptor field section for this event.

segment.source: Note The Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) defines string elements for enumerating information contained in the security descriptor.
segment.target: Note The Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) defines string elements for enumerating information contained in the security descriptor.

segment.source: SID of specific security principal, or reserved (pre-defined) value, for example: BA (BUILTINADMINISTRATORS), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the list of possible values in the table below:
segment.target: SID of specific security principal, or reserved (pre-defined) value, for example: BA (BUILTINADMINISTRATORS), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the list of possible values in the table below:

segment.source: "P” - SDDLPROTECTED, Inheritance from containers that are higher in the folder hierarchy are blocked.
segment.target: "P” - SDDLPROTECTED, Inheritance from containers that are higher in the folder hierarchy are blocked.

segment.source: "AI" - SDDLAUTOINHERITED, Inheritance is allowed, assuming that "P" Is not also set.
segment.target: "AI" - SDDLAUTOINHERITED, Inheritance is allowed, assuming that "P" Is not also set.

segment.source: "AR" - SDDLAUTOINHERITREQ, Child objects inherit permissions from this object.
segment.target: "AR" - SDDLAUTOINHERITREQ, Child objects inherit permissions from this object.

segment.source: "OA" - OBJECT ACCESS ALLOWED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).
segment.target: "OA" - OBJECT ACCESS ALLOWED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).

segment.source: "OD" - OBJECT ACCESS DENIED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).
segment.target: "OD" - OBJECT ACCESS DENIED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).

segment.source: "CI" - CONTAINER INHERIT: Child objects that are containers, such as directories, inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.
segment.target: "CI" - CONTAINER INHERIT: Child objects that are containers, such as directories, inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.

segment.source: "OI" - OBJECT INHERIT: Child objects that are not containers inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.
segment.target: "OI" - OBJECT INHERIT: Child objects that are not containers inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.

segment.source: "NP" - NO PROPAGATE: only immediate children inherit this ace.
segment.target: "NP" - NO PROPAGATE: only immediate children inherit this ace.

segment.source: "IO" - INHERITANCE ONLY: ace doesn’t apply to this object, but may affect children via inheritance.
segment.target: "IO" - INHERITANCE ONLY: ace doesn’t apply to this object, but may affect children via inheritance.

segment.source: rights: A hexadecimal string which denotes the access mask or reserved value, for example: FA (File All Access), FX (File Execute), FW (File Write), etc.
segment.target: rights: A hexadecimal string which denotes the access mask or reserved value, for example: FA (File All Access), FX (File Execute), FW (File Write), etc.

segment.source: accountsid: SID of specific security principal, or reserved value, for example: AN (Anonymous), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the table above for more details.
segment.target: accountsid: SID of specific security principal, or reserved value, for example: AN (Anonymous), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the table above for more details.

segment.source: For more information about SDDL syntax, see these articles: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc230374.aspx, https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/aa374892(v=vs.85).aspx.
segment.target: For more information about SDDL syntax, see these articles: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc230374.aspx, https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/aa374892(v=vs.85).aspx.

segment.source: For 4911(S): Resource attributes of the object were changed.
segment.target: For 4911(S): Resource attributes of the object were changed.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows object types (“Object Type”), for example File or Key, monitor this event for the corresponding “Object Type.”
segment.target: If you need to monitor events related to specific Windows object types (“Object Type”), for example File or Key, monitor this event for the corresponding “Object Type.”

segment.source: If you need to monitor all changes to specific files or folders (in this case, changes to resource attributes), monitor for the “Object Name” that corresponds to the file or folder.
segment.target: If you need to monitor all changes to specific files or folders (in this case, changes to resource attributes), monitor for the “Object Name” that corresponds to the file or folder.

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”

segment.source: You can track changes when, for example, a file was marked as High Impact, or was changed from High Impact to Medium Impact, or a resource was marked as a data type for a specific department and so on.
segment.target: You can track changes when, for example, a file was marked as High Impact, or was changed from High Impact to Medium Impact, or a resource was marked as a data type for a specific department and so on.

segment.source: This event can help track changes and resource attribute assignments, which you can see in “Original Security Descriptor” and “New Security Descriptor” fields.
segment.target: This event can help track changes and resource attribute assignments, which you can see in “Original Security Descriptor” and “New Security Descriptor” fields.
